journal-title-group.journal-title: Mosaic: A Journal for the Interdisciplinary Study of Literature

title-group.article-title: Cognitive Psychology and Whitman's "Song of Myself"

ref.mixed-citation: Arnold M. Ludwig, "Altered States of Consciousness," Archives of General Psychiatry, XV (1966), 225.
Recorded in Richard Maurice Bucke, Cosmic Consciousness: A Study in the Evolution of the Human Mind (New York, 1969), p. 236.
Quoted in Roger Asselineau, The Evolution of Walt Whitman: Part II: The Creation of a Book (Cambridge, Mass., 1962), p. 101.
Walt Whitman, "Song of Myself," in Leaves of Grass: The First (1855) Edition, ed. Malcolm Cowley (New York, 1959), Section I, line 5
Arthur Deikman, "Bimodal Consciousness and the Mystic Experience," in Symposium on Consciousness, ed. P.R. Lee, R.E. Ornstein, D. Galin, A. Deikman and Charles T. Tart (New York, 1977), pp. 67-88.
Deane H. Shapiro, Jr., "Meditation as an Altered State of Consciousness: Contributions of Western Behavioral Science," Journal of Transpersonal Psychology, XV (1983), 61-81.
Daniel Goleman, "The Buddha on Meditation and States of Consciousness," in Transpersonal Psychologies, ed. Charles T. Tart (New York, 1975), pp. 205-30.
Claudio Naranjo and Robert E. Ornstein, On the Psychology of Meditation (New York, 1971), pp. 11-12.
Daniel P. Brown, "A Model for the Levels of Concentrative Meditation," International Journal of Clinical and Experimental Hypnosis, XXV (1977), 242-43.
Jerome S. Bruner, "On Perceptual Readiness," Psychological Review, LXIV (1957), 123-52.
James J. Gibson, The Ecological Approach to Visual Perception (Boston, 1979).
Ulric Neisser, Cognitive Psychology (New York, 1967); Robert E. Ornstein, The Psychology of Consciousness (New York, 1975).
Victor Shklovsky, "Art as Technique," in Russian Formalist Criticism, trans, and ed. Lee T. Lemon and Marion J. Reis (Lincoln, 1965), p. 12.
Roman Jakobson, "Closing Statement: Linguistics and Poetics," in Style in Language, ed. Thomas A. Sebeok (Cambridge, Mass., 1960), pp. 350-77.
Barbara Hermstein Smith, Poetic Closure: A Study of How Poems End (Chicago, 1968), pp. 98-99.
Gay Wilson Allen, Walt Whitman 's Handbook (New York, 1957), p. 387.
Lawrence Buell, Literary Transcendentalism: Style and Vision in the American Renaissance (Ithaca, 1973), p. 169.
Edward D. Snyder, Hypnotic Poetry: A Study of Trance-Inducing Technique in Certain Poems and Its Literary Significance (Philadelphia, 1930)
Snyder and Ronald E. Shor, "Trance-Inductive Poetry: A Brief Communication," International Journal of Clinical and Experimental Hypnosis, XXXI (1983), 1-7.
Buell, "Transcendentalist Catalogue Rhetoric: Vision versus Form," American Literature, XL (1969), 327.
Robert E. L. Masters and Jean Houston, Mind Games : The Guide to Inner Space (Ne w York, 1972).
James E. Miller, Jr., '"Song of Myself as Inverted Mystical Experience," in A Critical Guide to "Leaves of Grass" (Chicago, 1979), p. 11
Diane Kepner, "From Spears to Leaves: Walt Whitman's Theory of Nature in 'Song of Myself."American Literature, LI (1979), 199.
Julian M. Davidson, "The Physiology of Meditation and Mystical States of Consciousness," Perspectives in Biology and Medicine, XIX (1976), 370.
W.T. Stace, Mysticism and Philosophy (New York, 1950), p. 290.

Paul Ricoeur, "Creativity in Language: Word, Polysemy, Metaphor," in Language and Language Disturbances: The Fifth Lexington Conference on Pure and Applied Phenomenology, ed. W.W. Strauss (Pittsburgh, 1974), p. 71.
Charles Feidelson, Jr., Symbolism and American Literature (Chicago, 1953), p. 3.
Whitman, "Democratic Vistas," in Walt Whitman: "Leaves of Grass" and Selected Prose, ed. Sculley Bradley (New York, 1949), pp. 539-40.
Reuven Tsur, What is Cognitive Poetics?, Papers in Cognitive Poetics I (Tel-Aviv University, 1983), particularly p. 42.
William James, The Varieties of Religious Experience: A Study in Human Nature (New York, 1958), p. 311.
